--- title: "Data visualization" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: "lecture-1-resources/preview.png" data-background-size: "30%" data-background-opacity: "0.6" format: revealjs: code-overflow: wrap width: 1600 height: 900 fig-align: center default-image-extension: svg fig-width: 8 fig-height: 6 chalkboard: true image: "lecture-1-resources/preview.png" editor: markdown: wrap: sentence --- ## Purpose ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} 1. Get you excited about storytelling with data 2. Show some tips and tricks to make your maps and charts pop ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} [Hans Rosling's *the best stats you've ever seen*](https://www.ted.com/talks/hans_rosling_the_best_stats_you_ve_ever_seen) ::: ::: ::: aside This is not about the software. Rather, it is about the theory behind communicating well with data ::: ## Structure ::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} 1. Overcoming Excel 2. Improving your maps 3. Telling a story with data 4. Reproducing figures for publication ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/overcoming_excel.png){fig-align='center' width=512} ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: aside A cartoon in the style of Aardman Animations depicting an animatronic computer fighting with a spreadsheet, vibrant green lighting ::: ## Everything is a story ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/abed.PNG){fig-align='center' width=869} ::: ::: ## Dan Harmon's Story Circle ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/story-circle.jpg){fig-align='center' width=450} ::: ::: ## Our Story Circle ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/story-circle.jpg){fig-align='center' width=450} ::: ::: ::: notes Zone of comfort: Data in excel Want something: to be better at communicating with your data Enter an unfamiliar situation: Looking closely at maps and charts Adapt to it: Practice discussing the differences Get what they wanted: Banging chart skills Pay a heavy price: Hard to concentrate - relax with an inspiring video Return to familiar situation: your projects Having changed: I hope you learn something. ::: ## Overcoming Excel
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ::: notes Excel itself is not a bad tool. It is very popular! See the info on jobs that require it. ::: ## Overcoming Excel
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: [*Formby et al* (2017) Microsoft Excel: Is It An Important Job Skill for College Graduates?](https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ1140801.pdf) ## Overcoming Excel
### Takeaways: ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} 1. You will likely use Excel in the future üìä 2. Excel's default plots and tables can be improved upon üìà 3. Simple rules can help you make your message clear üíé ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: ## {background-color="#e99869" background-image="lecture-1-resources/preview.png" background-position="left" background-size="contain"} ::: {style="position: absolute; left: 480px; top: 200px; height: 525px; width: 1500px; background-color: #69b1e9; padding: 20px; padding-left: 50px; box-shadow: 15px 15px 0px 0px #a9bcd2; border-radius: 5px;"} [Overcoming Excel]{style="font-size: 120px; font-weight: bold; line-height: 1em; margin: 0px"}
[Charts]{style="font-size: 60px; font-weight: bold;"} ::: ## Overcoming Excel: Column plot
::: columns ::: {.column width="30%"} - We often encounter datasets containing simple amounts ü§è - Here is some data on a sample of Swedish musical artists üéµ - I put this data into Excel, and asked for a recommended chart üìä ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Swedish musical artists

``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Your turn ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

## Tip 1: Avoid rotated axis labels ### Ugly ü§¢ ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/excel_1.png){fig-align='center' width=406} ::: ::: ## Tip 1: Avoid rotated axis labels ### Flip axes so that the text is easier to read üëì ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/excel_2.png){fig-align='center' width=406} ::: ::: ## Tip 2: Pay attention to the order of the bars ### Bad üëé ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/excel_1.png){fig-align='center' width=406} ::: ::: ## Tip 2: Pay attention to the order of the bars ### It is clear that Jos√© Gonz√°lez recieves more streams than Robyn ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/excel_3.png){fig-align='center' width=406} ::: ::: ## Tip 3: Consider your titles, labels and axes ### UninformativeÔ∏è ‚ùó ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/excel_1.png){fig-align='center' width=406} ::: ::: ## Tip 3: Consider your titles, labels and axes ### Note the title, x-axis title, x-axis labels üìô ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/excel_4.png){fig-align='center' width=560} ::: ::: ## Tip 3: Consider your titles, labels and axes ### Titles and captions have different application areas :::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Figure 1: Monthly streams for Swedish musical artists. Data sources: [Spotify charts](https://charts.spotify.com/home) in November 2022](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## We can use dots instead of bars ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## We can use dots instead of bars ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## Dots are preferable if we want to truncate the axes Dataset: Solar panels in Sweden ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## Dots are preferable if we want to truncate the axes
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: [Bar lengths do
not accurately
represent the
data values]{.absolute bottom="10%" right="0%"} ## Dots are preferable if we want to truncate the axes
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: [Key features
of the data
are obscured]{.absolute bottom="10%" right="0%"} ## Dots are preferable if we want to truncate the axes
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## {background-color="#e99869" background-image="lecture-1-resources/preview.png" background-position="left" background-size="contain"} ::: {style="position: absolute; left: 480px; top: 200px; height: 525px; width: 1500px; background-color: #69b1e9; padding: 20px; padding-left: 50px; box-shadow: 15px 15px 0px 0px #a9bcd2; border-radius: 5px;"} [Overcoming Excel]{style="font-size: 120px; font-weight: bold; line-height: 1em; margin: 0px"}
[Tables]{style="font-size: 60px; font-weight: bold;"} ::: ## Overcoming Excel: Tables :::: columns ::: {.column width="30%"} - We often encounter datasets containing simple amounts ü§è - Here is some data on a sample of Swedish musical artists üéµ - I put this data into Excel, and asked it to insert a table üóÉÔ∏è ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Swedish musical artists
Rank Artist Monthly listeners (m)

3 Jos√© Gonz√°lez ‚Äá4.07

02:30
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1-resources/excel_tab_1.png){fig-align='center' width=374} ::: ::: Discuss with your neighbour: - What do we like? - What is confusing? ## {background-color="FFFFFF"} :::: columns ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: {.column width="80%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Key rules for table layout
Number Rule
1 Do not use vertical lines.
2 Do not use heavy horizontal lines between data rows. (Horizontal lines as separator between the title row and the first data row or as frame for the entire table are fine.)
3 Text columns should be left aligned.
4 Number columns should be right aligned and should use the same number of decimal digits throughout.
5 Columns containing single characters are centred.
6 The header fields are aligned with their data, i.e., the heading for a text column will be left aligned and the heading for a number column will be right aligned.
Source: Claus Wilke's Fundamentals of Data Visualization
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: :::: ## Let's apply these rules :::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Key rules for table layout
Number Rule
1 Do not use vertical lines.
2 Do not use heavy horizontal lines between data rows. (Horizontal lines as separator between the title row and the first data row or as frame for the entire table are fine.)
3 Text columns should be left aligned.
4 Number columns should be right aligned and should use the same number of decimal digits throughout.
5 Columns containing single characters are centred.
6 The header fields are aligned with their data, i.e., the heading for a text column will be left aligned and the heading for a number column will be right aligned.
Source: Claus Wilke's Fundamentals of Data Visualization
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Table A](lecture-1-resources/excel_tab_2.png){fig-align='center' width=404} ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Table B](lecture-1-resources/excel_tab_3.png){fig-align='center' width=404} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Let's apply these rules :::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Key rules for table layout
Number Rule
1 Do not use vertical lines.
2 Do not use heavy horizontal lines between data rows. (Horizontal lines as separator between the title row and the first data row or as frame for the entire table are fine.)
3 Text columns should be left aligned.
4 Number columns should be right aligned and should use the same number of decimal digits throughout.
5 Columns containing single characters are centred.
6 The header fields are aligned with their data, i.e., the heading for a text column will be left aligned and the heading for a number column will be right aligned.
Source: Claus Wilke's Fundamentals of Data Visualization
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Table C](lecture-1-resources/excel_tab_4.png){fig-align='center' width=385} ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Table D](lecture-1-resources/excel_tab_5.png){fig-align='center' width=396} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Plotting related time series Dataset: Fertility and births outside of marriage in Denmark üá©üá∞ and Greece üá¨üá∑. Default choice for plotting is two line plots ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-37-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## Plotting related time series
:::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ### Pros üëç - Familiar ### Cons üëé - Hard to keep track of each series - Difficult to compare movements across short periods ::: :::: ## An alternative: time on a third axis
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## What have we learned?
:::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-40-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} - Both countries saw a large drop in fertility from the 1960s until the 1980s - In Denmark, after 1970 we see an increase in the share of children born outside of marriage - In contrast, Greek families have relatively few children outside of marriage. - After 1990, Danish fertility increased from 1.3 to 1.8, while Greek fertility remained at 'lowest-low' levels, below replacement. ::: :::: ## What have we changed?
:::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-41-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} - Indicators on the x- and y-axis and then show time with text labels - Legend is replaced with colour coded title - Colours have meaning (main colour of country flag) - Percentage labels on the y-axis ::: :::: ## Giving context Sometimes we may want to show a particular series of data in its correct context. For instance, in our line graph above which showed the evolution of the share of births outside of marriage in **Denmark and Greece**, we might want to know if these two represent the **extremes** within Europe. ## Giving context Do **Denmark and Greece** represent the **extremes** of the share of children born outside of marriage in Europe?
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-42-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## Giving context with an average One way to do this would be to show an average for Europe ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-43-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## Giving context with an interval ribbon ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-44-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## Giving context with all of the data This is silly ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-45-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960} ::: ::: ## Giving context with all of the data Here we [highlight]{style="color: #C60C30;"} the [series]{style="color: #0D5EAF;"} we are interested in and draw in the remaining series in [grey]{style="color: #7f7f7f;"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-46-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ## What have we changed?
:::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lecture-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-47-1.png){fig-align='center' width=768} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} - Shows each of the series - We can see that Denmark is a leader in the beginning, but is caught up by other nations - Does not hide outliers - Makes clear the trends in your countries of interest ::: :::: ## Legends colour dots by region. ## Tips for polishing your figures ::: {.cell} ::: ## Dataset: Daily hours between sunrise and sunset for various locations in 2022 ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Sunrise and sunset time
City Date Hours between sunrise and sunset month

``` ::: ::: ## Dataset: Locations of cities on a map ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
